DataElement.preferredName: Hematology Serum Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol Laboratory Procedure Lower Limit of Normal Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the value, units of measure not specified, of the lowest value of the range of statistical characteristics related to examination of blood for Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol which is associated with atherosclerosis, myocardial infarctions and strokes.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hematology Serum Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol Laboratory Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Examination of blood for Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol which is associated with atherosclerosis, myocardial infarctions and strokes. [Manually-curated]

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Hematology; the branch of medicine that deals with the blood and blood-forming organs and the diseases thereof.

Concepts.definition: The branch of medicine that deals with the blood and blood-forming organs and the diseases thereof.

Property.preferredName: Serum Low Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol Laboratory Procedure
Property.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.:Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is a lipoprotein that carries cholesterol around the body, for use by various cells.  LDL transports cholesterol to the arteries and increased levels are associated with atherosclerosis, and thus myocardial infarctions and strokes. This is why cholesterol inside LDL lipoproteins is called bad cholesterol. (from Wikipedia):The principal sterol of all higher animals, distributed in body tissues, especially the brain and spinal cord, and in animal fats and oils. (MSH98):A medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood, urine, or other substance from the body. Tests can help determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, check to see if treatment is working, or monitor the disease over time.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

A lipoprotein that carries cholesterol around the body, for use by various cells.  LDL transports cholesterol to the arteries and increased levels are associated with atherosclerosis, and thus myocardial infarctions and strokes. This is why cholesterol inside LDL lipoproteins is called bad cholesterol.

An animal sterol found in the body tissues (and blood plasma) of vertebrates. It can be found in large concentrations within the liver, spinal cord, and brain. Cholesterol is an important component of the membranes of cells, providing stability. It is the major precursor for the synthesis of vitamin D, of the various steroid hormones, including cortisol, cortisone, and aldosterone in the adrenal glands, and of the sex hormones progesterone, estrogen, and testosterone.  Cholesterol also has an important role for the brain synapses as well as in the immune system.  In conditions featuring elevated low density lipoproteins (LDL), cholesterol often forms plaque deposits in the walls of arteries, a condition known as atherosclerosis, which is a major contributor to coronary heart disease and other forms of cardiovascular disease.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 5/21/14 unretired DEC as part of Rel CDE w Retired DEC review, associated CDE used by other context, added CDE CS/CSI.  jc  2/9/12 - Retired as part of content cleanup activities per concurrence with Jenny Larkin (NHLBI).  8/2/07-DEC released per FBPP review team direction.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the value, units of measure not specified, of the lowest value of the range of statistical characteristics that represent accepted standard, non-pathological patterns, for a particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The bottom of the normal range for a particular laboratory result.:The information contained in a data field.

Concepts.definition: The lowest value of the range of statistical characteristics that are supposed to represent accepted standard, non-pathological pattern for particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.
The information contained in a data field. It may represent a numeric quantity, a textual characterization, a date or time measurement, or some other state, depending on the nature of the attribute.
